results.title: Redfern Beach (D)
results.creator_credit: Catriona McKenzie, Yvonne Maden, Rachel Roberts and AFTRS
results.brief_description: An islander Max (Michael Huahihe) finds himself working at a fish processing plant and struggles to be accepted. Unsure of the violent lifestyle, he attempts to move on once given perspective when befriended by Harry (Tony Barry), a local fisherman and his new lover, Phaedra.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catriona McKenzie, Yvonne Maden, Rachel Roberts and AFTRS

results.title: Makin pitchas (A)
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description: Makin Pitchas is a compilation of four short films made by young Kooris who are a part of the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Cooperative (BADAC). The project was an initiative funded by VicHealth to encourage young Kooris to explore and articulate their experiences of mental health issues, most particularly family issues, grief, conflict, racism and bullying. The final product is intended to promote discussion of mental health issues among young people in Indigenous communities as well as acting as a tool for cross cultural education in mainstream organisations. “Believe in Yourself” (dir. Tim Stares) is the story of Dave, a koori youth who feels alienated and discouraged by his parents who would prefer he drop out of school and lay bricks for his father rather than follow his dream to be a filmmaker. “A World of Colour” (dir. Myles Walsh) focuses on a mediation session, after a basketball game turns into a racial slagging match. “Goodnight Irene” (dir. Tim Stares) tells the story of Ruth, a young girl who has to do a history project about family’s pastimes. Unfortunately she cannot report anything to her teacher because the memories her mother has of her past are too painful to discuss. In “Verandah Dreaming” (dir. Myles Walsh) Verna loses her husband in the war and her son to drugs. Hope seems further lost when her grandson is sent to prison for stealing a car. However, with the help of the Aboriginal Legal Service, Sammy joins an Aboriginal Dance group and finds direction to his life.

results.title: Agnes, Maude & Pearly too
results.creator_credit: Erica Glynn, Alice Jacques, Charles Mitchell and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Two sisters meet up to play pokies on their deceased sister’s favourite pokie machine before scattering her ashes. Shortly afterward, their grief compounds and the truth of the past is revealed and confronted.

results.title: Strike your heart (A)
results.creator_credit: Wayne Barker, Nicki Lukacs and Strike Your Heart Productions
results.brief_description: Strike Your Heart is a gentle portrait of change; its happiness and heartbreak for a boy, a family and a culture. It is 1967 and Australian Aborigines have won the battle for their citizenship rights. New attitudes are being embraced by all and for a ten-year-old boy (Rami Rahman) living in the quiet coastal town of Broome, North-Western Australia, there are personal challenges that have to be faced - falling in love, his first kiss, heartbreak and departure from his close-knit Aboriginal family. Filmed on location in Broome, Western Australia - Wayne Barker’s homelands, with an indigenous cast from the region, “Strike Your Heart” is the first indigenous drama made in Western Australia. Cast includes Jimmy Edgar, Petris Torres, Attika Edgar, Alison Torres, Sylvia Clarke, Stephen ‘Baamba’Albert, Emmanuelle Torres, Brian T. Eastwell.

results.title: Dressing Dad
results.creator_credit: Sofya Gollan, Isabel Perez and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A short student film in which the filmmaker explores how the relationship with her father was transformed by the knowledge of his being a cross-dresser. Featuring interviews with her father and his transvestite friends, this work dispels many of the common preconceptions about cross-dressing and transvestitism while also being an engaging study of how families cope with aspects of individual difference and gender exploration.

results.title: Tent boxers (A)
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley and ABC-TV (Australia). Indigenous Program Unit
results.brief_description: Boxing is one sport that has produced some outstanding indigenous talent such as Lionel Rose, Tony Mundine and George Bracken. This documentary tells the story of the Tent Boxers who toured around Australia during the 1950’s and 1960’s as part of the Jimmy Sharman troupe. First-hand interviews by some of the Aboriginal tent boxers, including Roy Carroll and George Bracken, provide a detailed insight into the way these shows were run, the physical dangers, the control on and the lack of freedom experienced by the boxers and the exploitation of young Aboriginal men who found tent boxing to be a way of escaping unemployment. The paternalistic nature of the troupe’s organisers towards their boxers gave a feeling of family. However, the film shows both the positives and the negatives: Roy Carroll became Sydney’s first Aboriginal fight trainer and promoter and George Bracken, a champion of ringside boxing, but there was also an underlying attitude of racism by white Australians towards indigenous people, particularly during this period and some fights could get out of hand. “In 1971 promoters were required to have boxers and challengers medically examined before each fight and boxers were limited to one fight a week. This forced the travelling troupes out of business.”

results.title: Photographic memory: a portrait of Mervyn Bishop (A)
results.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Penny McDonald and Chili Films
results.brief_description: A documentary about the life and photography of Mervyn Bishop, one of Australia’s leading indigenous professional photographers who broke new ground during the 1960’s and 1970’s as a media photographer. Bishop’s extensive archive of photographs offer an invaluable document of aspects of Australian and Aboriginal life over the past 40 years.

results.title: Copyrites
results.creator_credit: Kim Mordaunt, Cathy Eatock, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: This program poses questions about what happens when Aboriginal concepts of ownership meet Western copyright laws in terms of Aboriginal art, its exhibition and distribution both nationally and internationally. Viewed as central to the lives of Aboriginal people, the art works elucidate a connection to the land and the vital importance of Aboriginal community, cultural and historical traditions. When these forms of expression are illegally reproduced and manufactured the consequences for the artists and the community at large loom further than the Western concept of violation of copyright, an issue that this documentary explores in depth.

results.title: Blood
results.brief_description:
Travelling through Australia with his film camera, Ivan Sen has visited many Aboriginal communities, from urban to prison to distant-rural. Photographing people in their definitive environments, he has created an installation which is a subtle and deeply moving meditation on skin, landscape, gesture and the many nuances of Aboriginal identities.

The work contains imagery of people who have all shared the same blood. The blood of the Gamilaroi people of Northern NSW.

results.title: Tears
results.brief_description: The lone desert highway leads from an Aboriginal settlement to a bus shelter which offers both the promise of opportunity and the danger of isolation. For the young teenage girl, the bus out of the desert means hope for legitimacy, freedom and an escape from the scars of a ruthless colonisation. For the boy, the escape might mean leaving behind the only family, community and safety he has ever known. Ivan Sen’s remarkable short film, utilising sparse dialogue and a harshly eloquent mise-en-scene, forces an audience to comprehend the terrible, seemingly futile optimism of will that is required of its young protagonists in imaging a future.
